text: You are in a tavern after a hard day of adventuring. The place is full of the normal patrons and a healthy amount of travelers who are in town for the local festival.

As you are sitting in a corner with a drink doing your best impression of Strider trying to scare off anyone who might even look at you. You notice that the guy at the table next to you is getting a little handsy with the wait staff. 

How do you respond?
option1Name: Sword in hand, I stand up and look angry
option2Name: I use magic to knock him out of his seat
option3Name: I don't. It ain't my business

text:
Of course, you do, that's what makes you a fighter.

You step up to the guy sword in hand.

What do you say?
option1Name: Take your stinking paws off her you damned dirty ape
option2Name: Nothing. I just bash his head in.
option3Name: Hey man, let's be cool man.

text:
Of course, you do, you're a wizard and you like to take the subtle approach.

What sort of spell do you want to use? Maybe just a little forceful hand to literally push him out of his chair? Maybe a fear spell so that he sees illusory monsters that are out to get him? Or, there's always Power Word Death.

Not saying anything makes you part of the problem. You don't want to be part of the problem, do you? 

How do you really respond?
option1Name: Sword in hand, I stand up and look angry
option2Name: I use magic to knock him out of his seat
option3Name: No really, it's none of my business

text:
Okay, look.

It's important for you to choose one of the other options for the game to go on. I'm trying to assign you a class here.
option1Name: Sword in hand, I stand up and look angry
option2Name: I use magic to knock him out of his seat

text:
The guy sneers at you and stands up. He has an unmistakable long scar going down one side of his face. You recognize him from a wanted poster that you've seen somewhere. His clothes are dirty and torn. They remind you of the bandits that you've seen in the area. 

He looks at your sword and pulls his own out. "I ain't no ape."

He steps in to attack.

You are amazed at how hard this guys head must be. You hit him with the broadside of your sword right on the side of the head. He fell out of his chair, and you figured that would have knocked him out cold, but he just stood up. It was a really satisfying hit too. It's not like you just tapped him. But now he's standing up, his own sword drawn, and he looks really angry.

He curses and steps in to attack.

The guy sneers at you. He has an unmistakable long scar going down one side of his face. You recognize him from a wanted poster that you've seen somewhere. His clothes are dirty and torn. They remind you of the bandits that you've seen in the area. 

"Mind yer own business."

The guy takes another drink of his mead, and when it's clear to him that you aren't going to let this go, he stands up and pulls his sword.

"Alright, if you want to make something of this, let's dance."

In this game, you will occasionally do some sort of check that will involve rolling dice. You will always roll 2 standard six-sided dice, add them together, and add in a relevant ability score. In this case, that will be Intelligence, because you are casting a spell. 

If you roll a 10 or better, then you will see the best possible outcome. 
On a 7 - 9, you will usually get what you want, but there will be some sort of negative consequence. 
If you roll a 6 or less, then something bad will happen.

The handsy guy charges at you as he swings his sword. You try to sidestep, but you stumble over a chair and fall on your ass. The guy starts laughing at you. The waitress also starts laughing at you. 

"He's my boyfriend," she says before taking the guy by the hand and leading him off to the sleeping rooms. 

You get back in your seat and pull the hood of your cloak up to try to cover your shame. That really didn't go as expected.

The handsy guy charges at you as he swings his sword. Without thinking much, you just kind of stick your sword out in front of you and the guy impales himself on it. It really wasn't what you were expecting to happen. 

The waitress screams and runs off. 

You find yourself, just kind of standing there with a dead guy on your sword. There's a huge mess of blood growing at your feet.

The handsy guy steps in as he swings his sword wildly. You easily deflect it with your sword, grab his wrist with your other hand, then pulling him forward and off balance, you hit him square in the temple with the pommel of your sword. He falls limply to the ground. 

The waitress thanks you for intervening, then hurries off to take care of the other patrons.

You feel a hand on your shoulder. When you turn to see who it is, you see the friendly round face of the barkeep. 

"That one always was a bad egg. Thanks for standing up for my staff. Your drinks are on me tonight."

The barkeep heads off to pour you another round. You go back to your table and you notice a few of the other patrons of the tavern giving you appreciative nods. No one really seems to notice the pile of ruffian in the middle of the floor. In fact, after a few minutes, you seem to completely forget that he's there.

Later in the evening, you are approached by a middle-aged woman.

"I saw what happened earlier, and I can tell that you are a person of action, perhaps you can help me."

After a few moments of standing there a bit dumbstruck, the barkeep taps you on the shoulder to get your attention.

"I appreciate you wanting to stand up for my staff, but this isn't the sort of place where we take to murdering our customers... even if they are wanted." He says in a growling voice. "Take the corpse outside, then go in the back and get a mop."

You do as he said, and once there isn't a drop of blood left in the place, the barkeep brings you a hot meal on the house. 

When you're halfway through eating it, you notice the barkeep talking to a local guardsman who came in. You see the guardsman give the barkeep some gold, and you realize that the barkeep totally just took the reward for killing the wanted guy. You think about calling him out on it, but you decide against making yet another scene tonight. You go back to enjoying the free meal.

After a few minutes, the barkeep puts a mug of mead on your table.

"I appreciate the thought of standing up for my staff. Don't feel too bad lad, they're both leaving in the morning, and you'll never see them again. You're lucky that went the way it did, you could have gotten a lot more than your pride hurt."

The barkeep leaves, and you slowly start to feel better as you enjoy the mead.
That's a good choice. It's subtle, it'll embarrass him, and he'll never know that it came from you.
Yes, this guy needs to be taught a lesson, and who better to do it than whatever terrors lurk in his own subconscious.

Really? You know that will make him just drop dead on the spot right?

Seems a little harsh for being a bit handsy.

Yeah, you're right. Down with the Patriarchy!

In this game, you will occasionally do some sort of check that will involve rolling dice. You will always roll 2 standard six-sided dice, add them together, and add in a relevant ability score. In this case, that will be Intelligence, because you are casting a spell. 

If you roll a 10 or better, then you will see the best possible outcome. 
On a 7 - 9, you will usually get what you want, but there will be some sort of negative consequence. 
If you roll a 6 or less, then something bad will happen.

Instead of pushing the guy over, you accidentally knock the waitress over. The handsy guy catches her on the way down saving for from hitting her head. She thanks him.

You decide that you should probably leave things alone. You watch the waitress slowly become more flirty with the guy as the night goes on. You know that he'll eventually break her heart and that she's too good for him. It's pretty depressing to watch, but there's not really much you can do. You've already made things worse.

You spend the evening trying not to watch and sipping your drink.

Well, you totally knock him out of his chair like you intended. You probably should have waited until he was distracted. As he was going down, he felt the push and looked in your direction only to see you holding your hand out in a pushing motion. Sure you're 20 feet away, but it was still pretty obvious what had happened.

Awesome! You time it right when he's taking a drink, so that he falls sideways out of his chair, spills ale all over himself, and hits his head on the floor. Not so bad that he'll have a concussion or anything, just enough to give him a headache for bit. 

The barkeep yells at him "You've had enough tonight, why don't you get back home."

Embarrassed, the guy picks himself up, glances around and notices that everyone in the place is watching him. Without a word, he heads out the door.
Satisfied that you've done a good thing without drawing any attention to yourself, you go back to sitting in the shadows enjoying your drink.

"You, Wizard" he says while picking himself up, "You looking to pick a fight?"

How do you respond?

You try to deny what he's talking about. No one else seems to have seen you make a spell, so it's your word against his.

Roll + Charisma to see if you can talk your way out of this.

You do?

Really?

That's not a very wizardly thing to do...

You can try, but it's probably not going to go well...
Good idea, you try to cast another spell to create an illusion to get the attention off of you.

Nobody believes you. In fact, you get kicked out of the establishment and are told not to come back anytime soon.
You distinctly remember the barkeep saying "No good wizard going around casting spells on my loyal patrons."

The worst part is that you miss the key thing that happens that really starts the story.

You spend the next few days bumming around town doing your thing, and then you die in a zombie apocalypse.

The End.

No one is really sure who to believe. The guy has had a lot to drink, but you look kind of sketchy sitting by yourself in the dark corner looking of arcane and wizardy. The barkeep announces that he's got his eye on both of you. One more outburst and you'll be kicked out into the rain.

You go back to working on your drink, but it's not as enjoyable now that you're being watched.

You totally talk your way out of it. Everyone thinks that he just fell over and was trying to blame that wizard guy in the corner instead of owning up to being a little too drunk.

Angrily he insults everyone's mothers and leave the bar. You go back to sitting in the shadows enjoying your drink.

Okay then.

You stand up, walk over to the guy who is now getting up off the floor. You probably say something that you think sounds really heroic about keeping his hands to himself, and you put up your dukes.

Your head really hurts. 

You open your eyes and look around, the bar is empty, and there's sunlight coming in through the windows. It seems you spent the night on the floor of the bar where you landed when you got knocked out. 

The worst part is that you totally missed the key thing  that really starts the story.

You spend the next few days bumming around town doing your thing, and then you die in a zombie apocalypse.

The End.

Your hand really hurts. You probably broke a finger when you punched that guy in the nose. He did run out of the inn holding a very bloody (probably broken) nose, so that's a win.

You lose @X HP. 

You'll have to use a healing potion when you get back to the room to fix your hand. 

You go back to sitting in the corner enjoying your drink and wondering what inspired you to do such a thing.

First there's the distinct sound of a fist hitting flesh, then the sound of a body hitting the floor, then silence as the entire place stares in shock.

Tonight's going to be one that people will talk about for weeks. It'll go down as the night a wizard totally dropped a guy twice his size with a throat punch.

A few people buy you drinks, telling you how awesome that was, and how the guy deserved that as he's a complete jerk. The waitress who he was being handsy with thanks you, and you go back to sitting in the corner with a smug sense of satisfaction.

No one is fooled by your illusion of a purple hippopotomus that suddenly appears in the middle of the bar. You get kicked out of the establishment.

You distinctly remember the barkeep saying "No good wizard going around casting spells on my loyal patrons."

The worst part is that you miss the key thing that happens that really starts the story.

You spend the next few days bumming around town doing your thing, and then you die in a zombie apocalypse.

The End.

You create the illusion of a dragon landing outside the inn. It makes a horrible roar, and everyone dives under their tables. Someones yells for you to get rid of it because you're obviously a powerful wizard.

You spend the next 20 minutes putting on a show of fighting off the dragon that is actually your illusion. You'd really rather spend that time sitting in the corner and enjoying your drink, but you're kind of committed to the lie now. Eventually, you make your way back inside and sit back down at your table. You're exhausted. 

And your drink is missing.
You order a new one, and go back to sitting in the corner.

You create the illusion of a town guardsman coming in the door.

It points at the guy, and yells "In the name of the king, you're under arrest!"

The guy looks at it, then dives out one of the windows and runs away. You make the illusion look like it gives chase out the window then dispell it once it's out of sight. 

Great job! The guy is gone, and no one knows that you had anything to do with it. You go back to enjoying your drink in the corner.

In this game, you will occasionally do some sort of check that will involve rolling dice. You will always roll 2 standard six-sided dice, add them together, and add in a relevant ability score. In this case, that will be Intelligence, because you are casting a spell. 

If you roll a 10 or better, then you will see the best possible outcome. 
On a 7 - 9, you will usually get what you want, but there will be some sort of negative consequence. 
If you roll a 6 or less, then something bad will happen.

You really need to learn to control your spells a bit better. Instead of casting it on the handsy guy, you cast it on the waitress. 

The way this spell works is that the target will see illusions of whatever their darkest fears are. It's really handy for causing distractions when you're in a fight. 

After screaming in absolute terror, the waitress ran from the inn. The memories of that illusion are going to keep her awake at night for weeks. She could have handled some handsy jerk. In fact, she was about to tell him to leave. But this spell is meant to be something that breaks the human psyche. Good job.

You spend the rest of the evening sipping your drink and contemplating your mistake.

The good news is that the spell totally worked. You don't know what that guy is seeing, and you really don't care. All you know is that he's petrified.

In fact, he fainted. The waitress got a couple of other patrons to help her carry the guy to one of the rooms. She keeps checking on him, and it's possible that she suspects something because she keeps giving you the side eye.

You spend the rest of the evening trying to keep a low profile.

That worked really well. The guy looked right at the waitress.
"noContinue no.. pleaseContinue noContinue"

Then he took off running. Whatever it is he's afraid of, he is projecting that onto the waitress. You doubt that he'll be back to this place.

You spend the evening feeling a bit smug sipping your drink.

If you roll a 10 or better, then you will see the best possible outcome. 
On a 7 - 9, you will usually get what you want, but there will be some sort of negative consequence. 
If you roll a 6 or less, then something bad will happen.

You wait until the guy takes a bite of his food, then you cast the spell. 

Nothing happens.

You felt the surge of magic when you cast the spell, so you know that it was cast.

You wait until the guy takes a bite of his food, then you cast the spell. 

The guy slumps over. There's a thud and a clatter as his head lands on the table knocking his dinner onto the floor. Someone screams, and the waitress checks on him. She announces that he's dead, and that starts a large commotion. Someone is sent to get his wife. No one can figure out what happened, but everyone is devastated. There's a lot of crying. It appears that this guy was one of the pillars of the community. 

You are very lucky that they don't know it was you.

You wait until the guy takes a bite of his food, then you cast the spell. 

The guy slumps over. There's a thud and a clatter as his head lands on the table knocking his dinner onto the floor. Someone checks on him, and there's a large commotion as people realize that he's dead. You overhear a few people talk with relief that he's gone. Apparently, the guy was pretty much all around a bad egg.

You continue to eat your dinner in peace.

You spend the rest of the evening trying to keep a low profile. You give condolences to people when appropriate, but mostly you just stay out of the way. You're forced to stick around at least for a while as it would be too suspicious for you to just leave. 

Eventually, things start to calm down a bit, and you're able to go back to sitting in the corner nursing a drink.

You make a small confused sound. The guy turns to you and winks.

You're sure that the spell hit. The only possible explanation is that this isn't some ruffian. You are looking at a very powerful creature. There are very few beings that can shrug off this spell like it's nothing, and you just cast it on one of them.  Your life is pretty much in his hands. If he decides to retaliate, you are not anywhere near powerful enough to defend yourself.
option1Name: Spend the rest of the evening looking away

text:
You decide that the best course of action, is to just lie low and pretend that nothing happened.

After a little while, the being whom you attacked gets up and walks out of the bar. As he passes by your table, he places a coin in front of you. You don't recognize it at all, and the script on it is unintelligible to you.

It's probably either cursed or some sort of death mark. What do you want to do with it?
option2Name: Pay your bar tab with it

text: In a desperate attempt to placate this being, you order him a glass of the most expensive wine in the place. It takes most of the coin that you have to buy it, and you're not sure how you'll afford to eat tomorrow, but at least maybe you will be alive tomorrow.

When the waitress delivers the wine, you can see her telling him that it came from you with your most sincere apologies. The being gives you a brief nod and smile. Feeling secure in that you aren't about to be squished like a bug, you go back to focusing on the drink at your own table.

Before you have a chance to reply to her, she continues,

"My son, Jimmy went missing this afternoon. He was last seen going into the mines. No one else will go looking for him. I saw how you stood up to that man earlier, would you please help me?"

"Thank you so much! I've been worried sick over him!"

With that, the woman leaves you. What do you do?
option1Name: Go at once to the mine
option3Name: Get a good night sleep first

text:
Jimmy is in danger, it's been two days already, and you know something terrible will happen if you don't get to him right away.

You finish the last of your drink, gather your things and head out the door.

It does seem like a resonable and prudent idea to ask around a bit before heading right into the mine. Maybe someone here can tell you something about the boy, or maybe even the mine itself.

Who do you ask?

It's very late, and you decide that going into some strange mine that's apparently been closed for a few years is something best done well rested.

You finish off your last drink, and head up to your room.

You find the entrance to the mine roughly a mile outside town. There is a faded sign welcoming you to

THE MINES OF IMMORTIA

The bartender is a short fellow with a large nose. You suspect that he might be part Gnome, but you don't ask. That would be impolite.

It's later in the evening now, and things are starting to slow down. You find him polishing a glass mug when you walk up to him.
Next time the waitress comes near your table, you flag her down. She's carrying a tray full of empty glasses as she heads back to the kitchen. She looks a bit tired and frazzled from a long evening.

You see a dwarf sitting by himself. He has a very impressive beard, and there's a mining pick hanging from his large pack that is sitting in on the chair next to him. 

You go over to his table, and take a seat opposite of him.
What do you ask about?

"What can you tell my about the boy Jimmy?" you ask.

The bartender sets his glass down, "That kid ain't nothing but trouble. He's always where he shouldn't be, and he's more interested in the dead than the living."

"I'm heading into the mines to find Jimmy, what do I need to know?" You ask.

"Many a person has gone into those mines and not come out. Those that do come out, usually come here for a drink before they go home." The bartender looks you over.

"I'm sure you'll be just fine."

"Could I get some provisions for a little spelunking expedition?" You ask.

"Hang on, let me see what I have available." The bartender says.
Now that you feel more prepared to go on this adventure, are you ready to head out, or would you rather start out after a good night's sleep?

"Here, I have this pack full of things that some other idiot was going to take into the mines, but he disappeared in the night leaving it in his room."

You gain the Attribute: Well Prepared! That's probably going to come in handy later.
Who do you want to talk to next?

"What can you tell my about the boy Jimmy?" you ask.

"I don't really know much about him. He doesn't come in here very often. Seems like an okay kid from what I've seen."

"I'm going to go into the mine looking for Jimmy, what do you know about it?" You ask.

"Well, I used to date a miner. He left 3 years ago when they closed the mine down. He said that the mine owners were having some trouble with miners disappearing, and monsters attacking."

She looks at the collection of empty mugs that you've acquired throughout the evening. 

"It's your liver." She says as she turns to walk away.
What do you ask about?
What do you ask about?

"I don't know him, but any kid who is going to go into a closed mine by themselves is both brave, stupid, and probably easily influenced. I suspect that something dark is brewing here."

"and I don't mean the coffee."

"What do you know about the mine?" You ask.

The dwarf sets down his drink and levels with you, "The mine here has been closed for years. I'm just passing through town. Sorry, that's all I know about it."

"I'm going to be heading into a mine looking for a missing kid. Do you have any advice?" You ask.

The dwarf frowns at you, "Don't, wandering around mines and caves with no idea of what you're doing is a good way to end up dead."

When he sees the look of dedication in your eyes, he continues, "If you insist on going, I recommend bringing plenty of supplies. Being unprepared kills as many miners as monsters."

"I recommend talking to the bartender about provisions."

You wake up feeling well rested. All of your HP is restored.

After grabbing a quick breakfast from the inn, you grab your things and head out to the mine.

You find the entrance to the mine roughly a mile outside town. There is a faded sign welcoming you to

THE MINES OF IMMORTIA
Double-click this passage to edit it.

You tell the woman to bugger off.

The rest of the evening is fairly uneventful.
You spend a few days hanging around town looking for work, but not really much pops up.
You die several days later in a zombie apocalypse. As life fades from you, you notice that the zombie who killed you looks like a Jimmy.

The first chamber in the mine is clearly a staging ground for deeper exploration. The remains of a wooden table that was long ago smashed by something are on one side of the chamber.

You can make out a variety of tracks going deeper into the mine.

The entrance to the mine seems especially dark and foreboding at night. The mine goes straight into the side of a mountain. The entrance is boarded over, but some of the boards are rotted, and others have been removed leaving enough space for just about anyone to squeeze through.
option1Name: Torch in hand I go in

option1Name: Torch in hand I go in

text: You are walking through a tunnel just large enough for a couple of people to walk side by side. You come to a section that is covered in wood planks. Without any other options, you carefully take a step on the planks followed by another and another when you suddenly hear a loud creaking.

You feel the wood beneath you begin to give. You jump forward just in time, and you reach your arms out and grab onto some of the more solid planks.

You find yourself dangling above what seems to be a rather deep hole. Unfortunately, it seems that you didn't come out unscathed. After you pull yourself up onto solid ground, you find that you have a bit of a gash on your belly. Lose @X HP.

You can tell that the wood is about to give away under you so you dive forward into a roll.

You find yourself laying on solid ground with a rather deep looking hole behind you. It's a good thing you took all those Gymnastics classes when you were younger.

You stand up and continue on your journey.

The wood crumbles out from beneath you. You scrabble to grab onto something, but everything that you can get a hand on breaks off in your grip. 

You fall

The ground below is quite hard. You know this because it really hurts when you meet it.

You lose @X HP.

The good news is, you're still alive. We still don't know if you managed to stay conscious through that severe head trauma.

Why don't you roll Constitution to find out.

Apparently not.

You wake up later with a pretty nasty headache. You don't know how much time has passed, but you think about poor Jimmy and you manage to pull yourself to your feet.

You manage to maintain consciousness, but you're pretty sure that you're going to be really sore in the morning.

After laying there for a minute, you manage to pull yourself back to your feet.

You don't black out. You don't even get the wind knocked out. Somewhere in the back of your head the pain registers, but you can't be bothered with it.

You pull yourself back to your feet to continue your journey.

You have reached 0 hit points and you have died.

This happens sometimes. The good news is that you can play the game all over again! Isn't that exciting?!?!

The torch that you were carrying went out in the fall, but you manage to find it because the hot end is still glowing. You get it re-lit and examine the room that you are in.

This chamber is a small natural cavern, not something that was carved out by the miners. There is a natural shaft going straight up (which you recently travelled through).

You can hear water running, and there is a small tunnel that you can squeeze through to go forward. Which do you want to do?
This dialog should not ever display
You crouch down and try to get some of your torchlight to shine down the tunnel. You can't see very far, but it looks like you should be able to make it at least as far as you can see.

Fortunately for you, you have that pack of supplies that you got from the bartender. You rummage in it and find some rope and a hook.

You spin it around and throw it up the shaft like some sort of ninja.

You feel the hook grab something fairly solid, and you shimmy back up the rope. You find yourself on the other side of the whole that you fell through.

After dusting yourself off, you continue down the tunnel.
You look at the long shaft. It looks very slick. Maybe if you had a rope or something you might be able to climb it. Since you don't, you decide that the narrow tunnel is a better option.

You walk down the tunnel another 50 feet or so, and you come to a large shaft.

There is a wooden platform in the shaft with a pulley system that allows it to be raised and lowered. The pulley is tied off to prevent it from going down. There is a wheel attached with gears to make it possible for one person to raise or lower the platform by spinning the wheel, or several people to operate it with a heavy load.

Of course, if you let go of the wheel without the rope tied off you will plummet to your death.

You bandage yourself up using a piece of fabric that you rip off of another piece of your clothing.

All bandaged up, you continue down the tunnel.

You start to crawl through the tunnel. It's difficult as you're still holding the torch in one hand and trying to pull your pack behind you. The smoke from the torch is stinging your eyes, and your elbow is getting sore from supporting your weight on the rocky ground.

After what seems like forever, you are relieved to reach a large chamber. The good news is that you can be done crawling and swimming. The bad news is that the tunnel comes out 30 feet up on a wall. You're a bit concerned about the long drop as you've recently had a bad experience with something similar.
This should never be typed

Fortunately, you are a wizard, and you can simply cast Feather Fall to get to the ground easily. That's pretty handy.

Of course, to cast a spell, you'll need to roll your Intelligence.

Okay, you mentally prepare yourself to climb down the wall to the bottom of the cavern. You peer over the edge, and it looks like there should be enough small ledges to use as handholds to lower yourself.

You turn around, and carefully start down the wall.

Of course, that means you'll need to roll Dexterity.

UmmmContinue this is awkward.

I'm so sorry.

The ground is very hard when you meet it. You lose @X HP.

You pull a feather out of your pocket, recite the right incantation, then step off the ledge.

You gently float to the ground. That all seemed too easy. You have a lingering sense of dread...

You deftly scale down the rock wall into the main cavern. 

Once you get to the bottom, you take a look around.
A bit shaken from the fall, you pick yourself up off the ground and look around.

As you're crawling, put your hand into water. You realize that the tunnel has a decline to it, and is flooded going forward.

You peer ahead, and it looks like it will be completely submerged within 10 feet. You really don't know if it will even keep continuing on underwater or if it will let out somewhere.

Of course, if it didn't that would be really boring for the narrative. So, you brave on.

When you're about to run out of your last chance for a good breath, you douse the torch and take a deep breath. Then blind and not knowing how long this will last, you continue on underwater.

Roll Constitution to see if you make it.

Apparently swimming underwater in a dark tunnel with no way to breath is not one of your better ideas.

The good news is ...

You're alive. You find the other end of the tunnel, and get to the surface just in the nick of time. The bad news is that the event left you exhausted and you are struggling to keep moving. You take a moment to relight your torch, and you continue on.

Swimming underwater in a dark tunnel with no way to breath? Psh... that's child's play.

You find the other end of the tunnel, and get to the surface with plenty of breath again. The experience was a bit thrilling. You take a moment to relight your torch, and you continue on.

Okay, you mentally prepare yourself to climb down the wall to the bottom of the cavern. You peer over the edge, and it looks like there should be enough small ledges to use as handholds to lower yourself. You're still pretty exhausted from your swimming adventure. This probably isn't a good idea. There really isn't much choice though.

You turn around, and carefully start down the wall.

Of course, that means you'll need to roll Dexterity.

You're so weak from almost drowning, that you don't have a chance in holding onto the edge of a wall. You slip almost immediately. Your head gets hit several times on the way down, and you land in a heap.

You are dead.

Would you like to play again?

You deftly scale down the rock wall into the main cavern. 

Once you get to the bottom, you take a look around.

You start climbing down the face of the wall.

You have a feeling of DÃ©jÃ  vu as your grip slips and you start to plummet to the bottom of the cavern.

The ground is very hard when you meet it. You lose 1 HP.
You carefully walk onto the platform and examine the apparatus and shaft. Above you is just the ceiling with the pulleys for the lift. The only way to go is down.

You grab the wheel to hold it steady, and you start to untie the rope. You realize that this operation would be a lot easier with two people as it's tricky to hold the wheel steady while untying the rope.

Roll Dexterity to see if you can do it.

The knot is a lot trickier to untie than you expected. You have to pull pretty hard on it, and when it finally lets loose, you slip and lose your hand hold on the wheel.

You are now falling, very quickly.

Roll Strength to see if you can grab the wheel and stop the fall.

The knot is a bit tricky to untie. You have to really pull to get it to release, and in doing so your grip on the wheel slips for a just a moment.

You are able to grab it again before you really lose control, but the platform drops a foot or two, then wobbles a bit.

You should have worn your brown pants.

It's a tricky operation, but you manage to keep a hand on the wheel and hold the platform steady while untying.

You begin to slowly lower yourself down the hole.

You've been lowering yourself for about 10 minutes. The light from your torch no longer reaches the top of the shaft where you started.

You get to a point where a couple of tunnels just barely too narrow for you to actually fit in meet the shaft.

You are attempting to peer down one of the tunnels when you hear a scraping/shuffling noise coming the other one.

You grab hold of the wheel, and it comes right off in your hands. You now have no way to stop the fall.

As you plummet to your death, you think that maybe you should have stayed out of abandoned mines.

Want to try again?

You grab the spinning wheel to stop the fall. The good news is that the fall gets stopped. The bad news is that you got flipped over when you grabbed it and you hit pretty hard on your back.

You lose @X HP.

The adrenaline rush of the fall allows you to spring into action. With two hands you grab the wheel gingerly and slowly bring it to a stop.

Now that you have it under control, you catch your breath, then slowly start back down the shaft.
You stand back up carefully not to let go of the wheel again, slowly you start to lower yourself further down the shaft.
After calming down a bit, you slowly start to descend down the shaft.

You turn around just in time to see a pair of goblins jump out of the tunnel and land on the platform.

They are holding short swords and look angry.

What do you do?

You realize that fighting goblins on a platform that is being held by a rope and will fall if you let go a wheel is a bad idea. 

So, you try to parley with them.

Roll your Charisma.
Should never see this

With one hand on the wheel, and the other raised in front of you, you prepare to cast magic missile at the goblins.

(You know better than to try a fireball when standing on a wooden platform.)

Roll Intelligence to cast the spell.

You pull your sword, and prepare to fight.

Roll your Strength

Whatever it is you said and did, it apparently wasn't the right thing.

The goblins spring to attack.

Using gestures you manage to get the point across that if you let go of the wheel, all three of you will plummet to your deaths.

The Goblins talk to each other in their strange language. They seem to see reason in that logic, and decide that you aren't worth the trouble.

Luckily, you speak Goblin.

You learn that their names are Bradley and Philip. They were angered by the platform moving as they had recently taken it back to the top where it belongs because some kid recently rode it to the bottom and left it there.

You promise them to take it back to the top when you are done with your adventure.

Philip and Bradley bid you farewell and wish you luck on your adventure. Because you were so well mannered, Bradley casts a healing spell on you. You regain all of your HP.

After that, they climb back into the tunnel. You proceed on your way.

The two goblins charge in causing you to let go of the wheel.

Two bolts of energy spring from your open hand, each one taking a goblin in the chest. The blasts knock them back, and they both hit the wall of the shaft, and fall through the gap between the platform and the wall. You're confident that they won't survive that fall.

You are falling. So are the goblins.

This sudden change in events makes them reconsider their actions. You may not speak goblin, but you're pretty sure that one of them just said "Oh no, not again."

You all hit the bottom. You lose @X HP.

You rest the platform on the ground, and take a look around.

With one hand occupied, you're fighting ability isn't so great. You manage to take down one of the goblins. The other one managed to get through and cut you with his sword.

You lose 2 HP.
Even with one hand occupied, two goblins are no match for your skill. You quickly dispatch both of them. They fall through the gap between the platform at the wall of the shaft.

This room is a naturally formed cavern that was once the main extraction chamber for the mine. There are a few broken hand carts on the ground near the central elevator shaft. There are places on the walls and columns where it is clear minerals were removed via pick-axe.

Also, everything is covered in spider webs.

You also see some large figures on the far side of the room, but you can't see them well in the torch light.

You found the Deep Gnome room.
However, I haven't written it yet. You must be playing in an alpha for beta version. If you are reading this and you bought the game on an app store, please send me a nasty letter because I forgot to come back and write this.

Not regular little spider webs mind you. These are really big spider webs. If you're not careful, you might actually get stuck in them.

As you're looking around the room, you hear a scuttling sound behind you.

You slowly turn around to see what's making the sound.

You see before you, the biggest, meanest, fuzziest, giantest, hugest (did I mention that it's really big?) spider that you've ever seen.

text:
You turn and start running from the giant spider. Unfortunately, the room is still full of giant spider webs making it difficult to run. 

You're going to need to roll Dexterity to get through the room.

There IS a torch in your hand. Setting the giant spider on fire seems like a brilliant idea, especially since you're reacting more and thinking less.

Of course to hit the spider with the torch in your hand, that's a strength roll.

That didn't work very well.

You tried throwing the torch at the spider in a panic. It bounced off it's carapace and you're not entirely sure where it went. But You are sure that it's no longer lit. It's very dark in here. 

There's also a giant spider that you now can't see.

I'll spare you the gruesome details, but it's time to restart the game.

RIP

As the spider opens it's dripping mandibles, you hit the spider in the eye with the torch giving you a moment to prepare yourself for a followup while it writhes in pain.
You'll never read this. Please tell me if you do.

With the spider backing up a bit, you now the opportunity to blast it with a fireball. Which seems a good idea since fire is apparently effective against it.

Let's roll some dice.

The spider backs up, giving you the opportunity to draw your sword and finish it off.

Let's roll some dice.

This spider seems to be more resiliant to heat than you previously imagined. It's on fire, but that doesn't seem to be bothering it much anymore. 

Also, some of the spider webs that are filling the cavern are catching on fire. 

It's time to make like a tree and get out of here.

The spider is now really on fire. You're pretty sure that it's going to die any moment now. Also all the spiderwebs filling the cavern are also on fire. It's time to make a quick exit from this cavern.

In a spectacular display of pyrotechnics the spider burns to a crisp, no longer able to threaten you again.

Well done.

As long as you are mindful of the many spiderwebs in the cavern, you are free to expore.
The fire seems to be causing the spider some pain as it backs up a bit giving you a chance to attack again.

It appears that the history of this cavern is rich indeed. The evidence that you noticed before of the mining is very apparent. When you search around a bit more,  it looks like there had been another occupant of the cavern before the spider arrived. There isn't a lot to go on, but someone had set up a camp here briefly. It's likely that they were driven out, or eaten by the spider.

While the spider might not be long for this world, it's still moving, and pretty scarry looking. Also, this cavern is getting pretty hot, so your best bet is to start running.

Of course, running in a room full of flaming spider webs with a giant spider that is on fire and may also be chasing you isn't a simple task.

Let's roll Dexterity.

Good times.

Let's roll Dexterity to see how that works out for you.

You trip on some spider webs that haven't caught on fire yet.

You land in more spider webs. They're really big, and really sticky, and your stuck. This is pretty much the worst thing ever.

But it gets worse when a giant spider that is still on fire walks up to you and devours you.

That's the end of your adventure.

text:
Okay, you're going to very carefully sneak through the cave and see what's on the far side.

That is going to require a dexterity roll.

That is a very bold decision. You sneak up to the trolls. You get a really good look at them as you approach. They are roughly twice as tall as you are, and are covered in rocky protusions. 

You're going to need to roll Dexterity to sneakily look through their belongings without waking them up.

Well, that was a good attempt anyway.

But not good enough. You are about 10 feet from the male cave troll when you step on a piece of wood that breaks and  makes a really loud sound. 

You find yourself standing there with no where to run when the cave trolls wake up.

As you're sneaking across the cave, you accidentally kick a rock that bounces off of a metal shield near the cave trolls making a loud GONG sound.

You quickly duck behind some rubble when you see the trolls begin to rouse.

You successfully sneak past the cave trolls. You get a really good look at them as you walk past. They are roughly twice as tall as you are, and are covered in rocky protusions. 

You are really glad that you don't have to worry about getting into a fight with them.

You get a really good look at the cave trolls as they stand up. They are roughly twice as tall as you are, and are covered in rocky protusions. They also seem to be pretty grumpy from being awakened by you.

"What you?" The female one asks in broken common.

How do you respond?

You get a really good look at the cave trolls as they stand up. They are roughly twice as tall as you are, and are covered in rocky protusions. They also seem to be pretty grumpy from being awakened by you.

text:
Once you are past the trolls, you see a smaller opening on the far side of the cavern that appears to go deeper into the mine.

Once you get inside, you relax a bit and lean against the wall. You didn't realize how much tension you were carrying in your shoulders as you went past the cave trolls.

That was pretty stupid. You walked up to the male sleeping troll, started rifling through his belongings, and accidentally stepped on his hand. He woke up with a yelp.

Before you get a chance to jump away, you feel a huge hand clamp down on your leg. Next thing you know, you are hanging upside down in a troll's hand.

You dig through a sack of belongings that is near the male troll. You find in there what appears to be an enchanted dagger. You are just tucking it away as you feel a troll's hand clamp on your leg.

Next thing you know, you are hanging upside down in a troll's hand.

You are a very sneaky individual. Like a ninja.

You dig through a sack of belongings that is near the male troll. You find in there what appears to be an enchanted dagger. You tuck it away, and very carefully, make your way across the cavern.

That is a pretty bold statement. Unfortunately, cave trolls don't have the sort of imaginative things that they tell their children about losing teeth. So, it doesn't really matter if they believe you or not. They respond by lifting their clubs and getting ready to smash you.
Telling them the truth does seem like it might be a reasonable thing to do. Let's roll your Charisma to see how that works out for you.

You tried explaining to the trolls that you needed to get through because you're looking for some kid named Jimmy who you think passed through here recently.

All that they really heard was "I'm a silly human and I want you to squish me." 

The trolls pick up their clubs to use for squishing you.

You have no choice but to defend yourself.

The trolls seem to believe your story about searching for Jimmy, but they are still very upset that you woke them. In recompense, they demand that you clean their cavern for them.

You realize that since they are much bigger than you are, that you're best off doing what they ask.

These are very reasonable trolls, and they recognize that it is perfectly reasonable for you to be looking for a missing kid, and that you really just needed to get by them and you were being very considering in not wanting to wake them up.

They wish you luck on your continued adventure, and let you pass through.

You stay hidden behind the rubble. The trolls spend several minutes looking around trying to figure out what made the noise that work them.

One of them picks up the sheild that made the sound and examines it for a minute before tossing it back down.

It takes quite a while before they fall back asleep and you feel comfortable finishing sneaking through the cave.

You wait until the right moment and jump out at the trolls to try to get a sneaky attack in.

The trolls, turn and look as you jump out, and they start to charge at you.

It takes you a solid couple of hours to clean the cavern to the troll's satisfaction. The male watched you very closely and several times told you to do something over. Once you are done, they let you go on your way. 

You make a mental note not to come back this way.

Once you are away from the trolls, you enter a smaller opening on the far side of the cavern that appears to go deeper into the mine.

You do manage to get enough on the ground around them that they slip and fall down. This gives you enough of a chance to just make a run for it.

You hold your hand out and millions of shards of ice fly at the trolls who hold their arms in front of their faces to protect themselves. 

Within moments the trolls are both encased in ice. Large icecycles jut away from the trolls in the opposite direction of you. You're pretty sure that eventually they'll be able to break out, but for the time being you are safe.
