You try to explain to them, that you'll need to do something else, but they won't take no for an answer. They pick up their clubs and step forward to smash you.

You pull out a deck of cards, and you have the male troll pick a card out of the deck. You then use some slight of hand to shuffle the deck and then reveal the same card that they pulled had picked earlier.

However, the troll can't really tell the difference between the cards and they aren't very impressed.

Maybe you should just try telling them the truth. Let's roll Charisma and see how that goes.

You pull a hankerchief from your pocket.

You show it to the trolls, both front and back. You then hum a little tune while you stuff the hankercheif into your closed fist. You then have the female troll blow on your hand, and you reveal a hankerchief that is now a different color.

The trolls' minds are blown.

After an applause that lasts long enough that it starts to be awkward, you tell the trolls that you must really be on your way. They are impressed with you, and wish you no harm. 

They wish you luck on your continued adventure, and let you pass through.

These are very reasonable trolls, and they recognize that it is perfectly reasonable for you to be looking for a missing kid, and that you really just needed to get by them and you are very sorry for interrupting their dinner.

They wish you luck on your continued adventure, and let you pass through.

You get a deadpan stare from both trolls. You're not sure if they don't speak common, or they just aren't impressed with your distraction.

They pick up their clubs with the intent of squishing you.

The male troll laughs. "Ha Ha, silly human, we no go outside."

It seems that your distraction was a miserable failure.

Maybe you should just try telling them the truth. Let's roll Charisma and see how that goes.

You can barely get out of the way fast enough when the trolls rush past you to go back the way you came. You're not sure how much time you bought, but it's probably a good bet for you to get out of this cavern quickly before they return.

Do you want to explore a bit first, or press on?
You sit down and lean against the wall of the tunnel. After a couple moments, your eyelids get heavy and you drift off to sleep.
While a rest seems like it might be a good idea, Jimmy can't wait. You've already wasted enough time getting here, and who knows how much further you have to go to find him.
You won't see this text. At least I hope not.

You dream of the town being on fire. There are hoardes of zombies everywhere, and you see a dark figure that seems to be directing them. You wake with a start, and find sweat on your brow.

You decide that getting a move on is a good idea.

When you wake up, you have the distinct impression that you had a really vivid dream. You can't really remember much about it. The only things left are the lingering sensations the smell of burned coffee and the image of the waitress from the bar.

You rub the sleep from your eyes as you stand up and get ready to go on your way.

You have a really strange dream. You aren't sure of what you make of it, but you get the feeling that all of your actions are being controlled by someone tapping a magical piece of glass.

It's disorientating, and makes you question reality a bit.

It's something best put out of mind so that you can continue on your way.

With the torch that you somehow managed to still have in your hand, you continue down the tunnel. This tunnel seems more of a natural formation than the one you initially entered.

After about 100 feet, the tunnel forks. You pause and look at each tunnel. From here, you can't really tell which way Jimmy might have gone. You're going to just have to pick one and hope for the best. Which way would you like to go?

After playing eenie meenie miney moe, you pick the left tunnel. It seems like just as good a choice as any. You have a strong sensation that this is indeed the right way, and you will stick with this choice no matter what.

You flip a coin and decide that the right tunnel is the way to go. After you walk a ways down the tunnel, you feel a rumbling and hear a loud crash coming from what is probably the other tunnel. You decide that you are glad that your coin chose this tunnel, and you give silent thanks to lady luck.

You walk for an inderterminate amount of time in which nothing interesting happens. Then you just sort of notice that this tunnel is really clean. There's no dirt on the ground, just bare rock. 

You rub a finger on the wall, and it comes away clean.

You're pretty sure it wasn't this clean back at the fork.

You come around a corner, and you see some bones, the head of a battle axe, and a gleaming gem just sort of hanging in the air in front of you.

Roll Wisdom.

After you walk a bit you come to a doorway. The actual door is gone, but the frame is there. It appears to be ancient. The tunnel you were walking in shifts into more of a hallway, but keeps going forward.

After walking in the hallway a bit, you stop because you notice slots in one of the walls ahead of you. You also notice that there are some different runes carved into the blocks of the floor going ahead.

Roll Intelligence to see if you know what they mean.

You don't see any possible reason to be concerned. Those slots in the wall are probably just from moles. The runes on the ground are probably just some sort of decoration.

You saunter on down the hall paying no heed to what you are stepping on.

It's pretty clear that you will set off a. trap if you step on one of the runes, or perhaps many of the runes. Either way, it seems like stepping on runes is a bad idea.

Since you don't know what runes are safe, you decide that trying to jump over them is the best bet.

Well, it really is obvious. An ancient buried structure in this part of the world would have been built by the worshippers of the ancient god Yhtia.

You start to step on the block that for the letter Y, but just before you put weight on it you have a sudden realization.

You carefully step on the blocks with the Yhtese runes that translate to:
Âµ
H
T
I
A

You find yourself safely on the other side of the trap. Just out of curiosity, you toss a random rock onto one of the blocks that was incorrect.

Dozens of arrows shoot out of the slots in the wall and embed themselves into the opposite wall.

It's a really good thing you studied Ancient Yhtese Culturebwhen working on your Bachelor's of Adventuring Degree.

Now that you are passed the arrow trap, you continue down the hall being even more careful to watch for any additional traps.

The passage continues on for quite a ways taking several turns but not branching until you eventually come to a door.

In Ancient Yhtese, the rune that translates to Y is taboo, so typically they wrote out Yhtia with a Âµ instead of a Y. 

You carefully take your foot off the Y without putting any weight on it.

You back up a ways down the hallway to give yourself some running room. Then you take off at a dead sprint to attempt to jump over the blocks with runes.

Roll Dexterity to see if you make it.

Just as you are about to jump, you notice that your shoelace is untied. Unfortunately, you are pretty committed to the jump at this point. 

As you jump, your shoelace is underneath the foot that you are pushing off with. This causes you to stumble, and fall on your face onto many of the rune blocks.

The fall itself didn't hurt, and a good many of the arrows went over your head. However, some of them are now sticking out of your side.

You lose @X Hit Points.

You give a great leap as you get to the edge of the blocks. Unfortunately, you don't leap quite as far as you need to. Your foot lands on one of the blocks in the final row. 

You hear a loud sound as hundreds of arrows fly out of slots in the wall. Luckily, you are well past the majority of them. Only a couple get stuck in you. 

You lose @X Hit Points.
With the grace of a gazelle, you leap clear of the runes and do a perfect plant on the far side. Your former track coach would be proud of the hitch-kick that you employed to get extra distance.

That hurts, but at least you're still alive. You're lucky that you didn't get hit by more arrows.

Confident that you have now tripped all the blocks that would cause arrows to fire, you pull yourself off the rune blocks. You lean against the wall, and pull the arrows out.

You take another couple steps forward to get clear of the trap.

There are two small arrows sticking out of you. One in your side, and one in your posterior.

They hurt more getting pulled out, than they did going in.

You find yourself safely on the other side of the trap. Just out of curiosity, you toss a random rock onto one of the blocks with a rune on it.

Dozens of arrows shoot out of the slots in the wall and embed themselves into the opposite wall.

That looks like it would have hurt.

You hear a really loud sound as hundreds of arrows shoot out of the holes. Many of them embed themselves into the wall opposite the holes. Many of them also embed themselves into you.

You lose @X Hit Points

OW! My Skin!

There are a lot of arrows sticking out of you. You walk the rest of the way past the blocks with runes on them that clearly had more significance than you thought.

You begin the slow painful process of removing the arrows.
Once you have all of the arrows removed, you can continue down the hall. You wish that maybe you would have given those blocks a little more levity than you did.
Randomly choose a room. This text will not display.

You reach out and try to grab the gem. You touch a transparent surface that feels a bit like Jello before you get to the gem. As soon as your hand touches the surface, you feel a sharp pain.

Roll Constitution to see if you are paralyzed.

A little bit of motion makes you aware that the gem is suspended in a Gelatinous Cube. 

Fortunately, you are not stupid enough to try to reach inside of a Gelatinous Cube. Many an adventurer has been consumed by them from the stories that you've heard.

Now you just need to figure out how to get past it.

Yes. You are now paralyzed.

Now that you are stuck, you can tell that your hand is engulfed in a Gelatinous Cube. You feel yourself slowly get pulled into it. While, you cannot move, the pain is excruciating as you feel your skin start to dissolve from the acidic nature of the beast.

The next several hours are filled with pain. When it finally comes, you welcome the release of death.

RIP

Your hand is engulfed in a Gelatinous Cube. Admidst the pain, you feel a slight tugging sensation pulling you forward.

You pull your hand away from the beast. While touching it the first time didn't seem to do any lasting damage, you're pretty sure that you don't want to touch it again.

Now to figure out a way past it.
Your hand is engulfed in a Gelatinous Cube. Admidst the pain, you feel a slight tugging sensation pulling you forward. You aren't immediately paralyzed, but you do lose @X Hit Points.
You pull your hand away from the beast. Now that you have learned the hard way not to touch it, you need to figure out a way to get past the Gelatinous Cube.

You look around to get some options. The passageway that you are in is approximately 10 feet wide and 10 feet tall. The Cube in front of you is also 10 feet wide and 10 feet tall. It's also highly acidic which is why the passageway is so clean.

It's also slowly working it's way towards you. You take a couple steps back.
Double-click this passage to edit it.

As a Wizard, it seems that the best option is to use magic to get past this thing. You could use something pretty destructive to attempt to kill it, or you could shrink it and just step over it.

Which do you want to do?

As a fighter, it seems that the best option might just be fighting the Gelatinous Cube. Of course, you don't really want to risk touching it, so you'll want to do it from a distance.

You could either use a crossbow, or you could throw something at it. Either one sounds like a perfectly reasonable course of action.

Yes, this thing is clearly a manace to adventurers everywhere, and the best thing to do is just to end it.

This sounds like a good job for lightening.

Roll Intelligence to cast.

Yes, shrinking it would be a more humane way to deal with the creature. The spell is only temporary and will allow you to pass without doing permanent harm.

Let's roll Intelligence to give that a try.

Maybe lightening wasn't a good idea. The Gelatinous Cube is definitely dead, but it sort of exploded. You are now covered in acidic goo.

You lose @X Hit Points.

Lightening certianly appears to be an effective way to get rid of a Gelatinous Cube, although it's definitely messy. The thing sort of exploded causing acidic goo to go everywhere. Your quick thinking got you to pull your cloak up as a shield to protect your skin. Unfortunately, now it's ruined.

You remove the tattered remains of your cloak, and carefully move on.

Lightening certianly appears to be an effective way to get rid of a Gelatinous Cube. The thing sort of melts into a puddle of acidic goo. The remnants of it's previous victims clatter to the ground. You think briefly about picking up that gem, but you decide that it's not worth dealing with the layers of acid on it.

You carefully step over the puddle and continue on your way.

You take off your cloak which is now covered in the goo, and use a water spell to wash as much of it off yourself as you can. 

You're probably goinng to have some permanent scars from this. At least the tunnel is clear and you can go on.

You continue down the tunnel. Before long you come to a transition where it goes from a natural tunnel to an ancient hallway. Instead of just rock for the walls, it becomes something that was crafted long ago.

The passage continues on for quite a ways taking several turns but not branching until you eventually come to a door.

It seems that you got something mixed up in the spell. Instead of shrinking the cube, you made it get bigger. A lot bigger... very quickly.

In fact, the spot where you are standing is about to be filled with Gelatinous Cube. 

Roll Dexterity to see if you can avoid becoming part of the cube.

The good news is that your spell worked. The Gelatinous Cube totally shrank. The bad news is that when you cast the spell the gem sitting inside the cube started to glow a bit. It must have been some sort of spell amplification gem.

You are shocked to watch the cube continue to shrink down to the point where you can no longer see it. Your best guess is that it has gone subatomic and entered the quantum realm. Time and Space no longer have any meaning for it. You have probably trapped it forever.

Your spell worked like a charm.  The cube shrinks down to about the size of a coconut.

You simply step over the cube, and continue down the path. You feel pretty good about yourself as you left a perfectly innocent creature unharmed. It'll be back to its normal size before long.

You were much too slow to jump back in time. You are now stuck inside the Giant Gelatinous Cube.

There is quite a bit of pain as you are slowly dissolved. Death takes a long time to come.

Would you like to try again?

You jump back away from the expanding Gelatinous Cube. You don't get away quite as quickly as you would like, and you get some of it's acid on you.

You lose @X Hit Points.

You successfully jump back.

You watch as the cube slowly gets bigger and bigger. You can see that it's having trouble with the fact that the tunnel which it already filled is not expanding with it.

You're not sure that you can really read the body language of a Gelatinous Cube, but you think it's probably in a lot of pain. Can they even feel pain?

You watch as the cube slowly gets bigger and bigger. You can see that it's having trouble with the fact that the tunnel which it already filled is not expanding with it.

You're not sure that you can really read the body language of a Gelatinous Cube, but you think it's probably in a lot of pain. Can they even feel pain?

The process takes a while, but eventually the spell wears off, and the cube shrinks back down to it's normal size. When it does, it does not go back into it's normal cube shape. You are confident that it died from the tunnel squeezing it.

Eventually you are able to get around it and continue on your way. Even if you are much delayed in that process.

Yes, using a crossbow seems like it's the more reasonable action. 

You take a couple more steps back to stay away from the Gelatinous Cube, and you get your crossbow out and ready some bolts.

You don't worry too much about aim as you really can't miss. It's filling the entire passage.

Let's roll some dice anyway. How about Dexterity?
[[gcthrowEnchantedDagger]]

Ok, so you do hit the Gelatinous Cube. It really wasn't possible to miss. However, you don't really seem to hurt it. 

Also, you didn't know until just now that a Gelatinous Cube could expunge something inside of it, much less that it could do so at a high velocity. Remember that battle axe head that was floating inside of it? It's now flying at you very quickly.

Roll Dexterity to dodge.

The best way you can think to do this, is to just keep hitting the cube as quickly as you can. You keep firing crossbow bolts at it over and over. The bolts seem to be doing some damage to it, so you don't stop.

You work yourself into a bit of a frenzy and you can hear yourself screaming as you keep firing, but it doesn't register that the voice that is screaming is yours.

You don't notice that you are getting splashed by some of the cube's matter that is flying off of it.

You lose @X Hit Points.

You take careful aim right at the ceneter of mass. With a slow exhale, you squeeze the trigger and release the crossbow bolt.

The bolt hits right in the center of the cube and hits the gleaming gem that was floating in there.

You see the gem start to crack, and light starts to come out of the cracks. You duck just as the gem explodes and sucks the Gelatinous Cube into some sort of alternate dimension.

The axe head hits you right in the head. Lucky for you, Gelatinous Cubes are not proficient axe throwers, and you get hit by the broad side. It still had a lot of force behind it, and you lose @X Hit Points. 

Also, everything goes black.

You dive out of the way of the axe head. Successfully avoiding losing your head. However, you didn't really take into account the small width of the tunnel when you dove. You hit your head on the rock wall, and everything goes black.

You sidestep the axehead as it's coming for you. Then you deftly reach out and grab it. 

Without thinking about it, you throw it back at the Gelatinous Cube. The axehead hits right in the center of the cube and hits the gleaming gem that was floating in there.

You see the gem start to crack, and light starts to come out of the cracks. You duck just as the gem explodes and sucks the Gelatinous Cube into some sort of alternate dimension.

You wake up later with a massive headache.

You sit up and look around, and the Gelatinous Cube seems to be gone. You don't know how much time has passed, and you don't know where the cube went.

These are things you probably should be worried about, but instead you decide to keep on going.

You wake up later with a massive headache.

You sit up and look around, and the Gelatinous Cube seems to be gone. You don't know how much time has passed, and you don't know where the cube went.

These are things you probably should be worried about, but instead you decide to keep on going.

You're now really curious what sort of gem that was. Unfortunately, there's not much you can do to figure it out.

With a shrug, you get back on your journey.

When you finally stop firing, there is nothing left of the Gelatinous Cube by a slurry of slime and bolts on the ground. After you catch your breath, you carefully step over it, and continue down the path.

The first thing you find to throw at the Gelatinous Cube is the Enchanted Dagger that you picked up earlier. 

With a thought of "easy come, easy go" you chuck the dagger at the cube.

Roll Strength.
[[gcThrowpotion]]

You quickly dig through the pack of provisions that the bartender gave you looking for something to throw. You find a small vial inside with a label that says Gelatinous Cube Removal Potion.

That seems really oddly specific, but very useful in this situation.

You throw it at the Gelatinous Cube.

With a lack of anything better to throw, you decide to throw a rock that you find laying nearby.

Roll Strength to see how that goes for you.

Well, the cube is kind of filling the. entire passage, so you can't really miss. However, the magic of the dagger seems to react badly with the Gelatinous Cube. 

Explosively so.

The cube bursts, pieces of it go flying everywhere. There is no way to avoid getting splashed.

You lose @X Hit Points.

You hit the Gelatinous Cube with the dagger pretty square in the middle. You still have no idea what sort of enchantment is on this dagger, but you do see a lot of pretty lights coming from it.

In moments, the light gets so bright that you have to avert your eyes. Once it's gone you look and you can see no trace of the dagger or the cube.

With the hallyway clear, you move on.

You have no idea what sort of enchantment is on this dagger, but it appears to be really powerful. 

The dagger goes clear through the Gelatinous Cube like a comet. It clatters to the ground in the distance. There isn't much left of the cube. You carefully step over the remains, pick up the dagger, and continue on your way.

You take off your cloak which is now covered in acidic goo, and use the cleanish parts to wipe as much of the goo off as you can.

You're probably goinng to have some permanent scars from this. At least the tunnel is clear and you can go on.

The vial breaks on contact with the cube, and the liquid inside gets absorbed by it. Theresult is almost instant. The Gelatinous Cube starts to shrivle and shrink. You can see steam rising from it.

After a few moments, there is just a misshapen lump on the ground. You decide that if you make it back to that same bar, you're going to give the bartender a really bit tip.

With the cube gone, you move on.

Ok, so you do hit the Gelatinous Cube. It really wasn't possible to miss. However, the bolt didn't really seem to hurt it. 

Also, you didn't know until just know that a Gelatinous Cube could expunge something inside of it, much less that it could do so at a high velocity. Remember that battle axe head that was floating inside of it? It's now flying at you very quickly.

Roll Dexterity to dodge.

You take careful aim right at the center of mass. With a slow exhale, you pitch the rock at the Gelatinous Cube.

The rick hits right in the center of the cube and hits the gleaming gem that was floating in there.

You see the gem start to crack, and light starts to come out of the cracks. You duck just as the gem explodes and sucks the Gelatinous Cube into some sort of alternate dimension.

You enter a large feasting hall. The first thing that you notice is the smell. The room stinks like a chicken coop.

Tables and other furniture in various states of decay litter the room. You stop and examine the one closest to you. While you aren't an expert, it appears to be several hundred years old. It also has large claw marks on it.

You just found the room that will be written about a rust monster. It's going to be the best room. It'll have lots of witty writing and you'll enjoy a mirthful chuckle. 

But, since it's not written, go to the alternate room instead.

You hold your torch up, and peer into the darkness as well as you can. You hear a deafening gutteral "bawk bawk bawk BAGOCK!"

Out of the shadows steps a creature that you have only heard about in legends. It resembles a chicken, but stands as tall as a man, it's wings are the leathery wings of a bat, and it has a tail of a snake.

It's a Cockatrice

As a worldly and experienced adventurer, you know that the Cockatrice is a deadly creature. This one is a large one. The gaze of a Cockatrice will turns it's victim to stone. The only cure is it's own saliva. Of course typically that comes into play when you are being eaten.

What do you do?
You see a good pile of tables off to one side that would offer temporary protection. Roll Dexterity to see if you make it there.
Double-click this passage to edit it.

You start to run, but the room is poorly lit, and you trip and twist your ankle. You sense a presence just behind you. You roll over and see the Cockatrice looming over you.

As it looks into your eyes, you feel a numbing sensation as you start to turn to stone.

Roll Constitution to see if you can resist.

You take off for the hiding place paying little heed to anything except getting out of danger. 

You're able to get to the stack of tables with little problem. There is a really good space underneath just for hiding in. The problem is that it's full of rather large eggs.

You make a run for the stack of tables that you saw. You have to duck and weave through other bits of furniture while being mindful of the dilapidated stone floor.

You are relieved that you  manage to get there completely unscathed.

You failed that roll. In fact, you just failed 2 in a row. That's unfortunate.

You feel everything go dark and cold as you turn to stone. You are now giant chicken feed.

Would you like to try again?

You feel a wave a nausia coming over you. You manage to roll over just as you expunge some of your most recent meal. It feels pretty rough coming up, and there are some rocky bits in it. You're pretty sure that you just lost some internal organs.

You lose @X Hit Points.

Suddenly the numbness goes away. You look at your hand and it's perfectly normal. You look back at the Cockatrice, and it seems just as confused as you are. You take the opportunity to scramble away and into a hiding place.
The Cockatrice starts to peck at your disgorged matter. You use the distraction as an opportunity to scramble away into a hiding spot.
Okay, now you're hiding from a really big chicken in the hall of ancient underground ruins. What are you going to do now smart person?
option1Name: Surprise Attack when it gets close
option2Name: Try to put it to sleep

text:
The nest has roughly a dozen eggs in it. You don't take the time to count them, so you aren't really sure. You have a larger problem to worry about at the moment. 

In fact, because you can't really hide without crushing all the eggs, you are just kind of standing there when the Cockatrice sees you.
You wait until the perfect moment, then jump out of your hiding spot to attack the Cockatrice!
this dialog will not display

It is quite obvious that the correct solution as a great and powerful wizard is to cast a sleep spell on the Cockatrice. This is the best solution for both you and the creature to survive.

Roll Intelligence to see how you do.
[[cocosleeppotion]]

Surely the pack that you got from the bartender has some way in it to deal with a raging cockatrice. 

You dig through the pack a bit, and you find a sleeping potion. Since you dont' really want to get close enough to get the Cockatrice to drink it, your best bet is to just throw it like a molotov and hope for the best.

Roll Dexterity to throw.

With a lack of any better options, you decide to sing a lullaby to this mythical beast that can turn you to stone with just a glance. You are either very brave or very stupid. 

We will let the dice decide which.

Roll Charisma to sing.

Ducking down in your hiding place, you prepare the spell. Once it's ready you jump up and shout "GO TO SLEEP!"

The cockatrice simply turns and looks at you.

Ducking down in your hiding place, you prepare the spell. Once it's ready you jump up and shout "Ukulala!"

A bit to your surprise, the Cockatrice is standing right on the other side of the table you are behind. It closes it's eyes, and starts to fall forward... right at you...

You put your hands out, but as it falls down, you go down with it and end up pinned by it.

Ducking down in your hiding place, you prepare the spell. Once it's ready you jump up and shout the verbal part of the incantation.

You watch as the Cockatrice falls to the ground, sound asleep.

You are now free to explore the room.
With a lack of other options, you decide that fighting this thing is the only way to stay alive right now.

It takes a lot of effort, but you are able to push the sleeping Cockatrice off of you. The only real lingering damage that it did is to cover you in it's stench.

You're going to have to live with that for a while.

You are now free to explore the room.

You spend some time looking around the room. It appears that someone was keeping the creature here as a source of large eggs.

You see near the far end a pile of broken statues.

You stand up and chuck the bottle of sleeping potion at the Cockatrice. It hits the cockatrice right in the head, which you think is an excellent result, except the bottle doesn't break, and now the beast is looking right at you.

You stand up and chuck the bottle at the cockatrice, which is actually almost within arms reach. The bottle explodes and sleeping potion goes everywhere. 

You yawn.
You feel really kind of sleepy, and that nice feathered thing there looks really comfortable. Without really thinking about it, you just kind of curl up on it.

You stand up and chuck the sleeping potion at the Cockatrice. You have impeccible aim, as it hits the Cockatrice right in the face and shatters spilling all over it. 

You watch as the Cockatrice falls to the ground, sound asleep.

You are now free to explore the room.

You wake up curled in a nice warm bed of Cockatrice. You aren't sure how much time has passed, but you are at least relieved to know that the Cockatrice is still asleep.

Being very careful to not wake it, you extricate yourself. You don't know how long it'll stay alseep, but you are free to explore the room.

You stand up and begin to sing the best lullaby song that you can think of...

which is Happy Birthday...

Your adventuring lifestlye is not very conducive to child rearing, and it shows.

The Cockatrice looks at you quizzically.

You stand up, and start to sing "Hush Little Baby". The COckatrice looks at you, but doesn't move.

Hopeful that this crazy plan will work, you keep singing.

The strangest thing happens, the creature starts to sing along with you. Not the words of course, but it carries the tune. In fact, it harmonizes with you a little bit.

It doesn't move from it's spot.

You are free to explore the room, as long as you don't stop singing.

Boldy, you stand up, and start singing "Baby Mine" just the way that your mother sang to you when you were just a wee little one.

The Cockatrice looks at you. Without meeting it's gaze, you keep singing.

It's eyes start to droop, and it's head gets heavy. Encouraged by this, you don't let the song stop. Just as you sing the last "Sweet as can be" the Cockatice lays down, and goes to sleep.

You are free to explore the room.

No Chicken/Lizard/Bat creature can stand before the might of your arcane powers. You shall smite this thing into oblivion. You prepare an arcane blast knowing that will finish it quickly.

Roll Intelligence to cast.

Okay, you are a guy with a sword. You need to use it to kill a giant chicken/lizard/bat thing. You got this. 

Roll Strength to see what happens.

You cast the blast at the Cockatrice, but your spell goes wide and instead takes out a support column. 

With a loud rumble, part of the ceiling falls in, and you jump to avoid getting crushed.

Roll Dexterity.

The Cockatrice leaps at you just as you unleash your bolt of arcane power. You bolt hits it at nearly point blank range and it flies backward and into a lump on the ground.

It takes you a moment to notice the pain in your leg. You look down and see a sizeable gash from where the cockatrice got it's claws into you. You lose @X Hit points.

The Cockatrice leaps at you. You shout "HADOUKEN" just as you throw a blast of energy into it's face. 

The Cockatrice flies backward and lands in a lump.

What a way to go. Squished in a giant underground monster chicken coop that you caused to cave in.

Your name will not be remembered.

Would you like to try again?
You avoid the majority of. the cave in, but you are still hit by a few rather large rocks. You lose @X Hit Points.
You do a wonderful triple backflip avoiding each piece of falling rock. The only downside is that you wish someone could have seeen it. It was amazing.

The good news is that it appears that the Cockatrice was crushed by the collapsing ceiling.

Now that you don't have a murderous chicken monster to worry about, you are free to explore the room.

As you approach the pile of statues, you notice that one of them isn't a statue at all. It's a teenage boy. He's unconcious, and seems to be roughed up a bit, but still in one piece.

Most of these have been here a long time and are pretty broken up. One in particular catches your eye. It's a teenage boy matching the description of Jimmy. Still in once piece, but irreversibly turned to stone. If only you had gotten here sooner.

The boy says:
"Yeah, I'm Jimmy. Did my Mom send you after me? She's always worrying."

"I'm glad you got here when you did, any longer and I would be just another statue." He looks at the other statues. "or pieces of one..."

"I came down here to work with a necromancer. He tossed me out here because I made too many mistakes. Some apprentice I turned out to be."

"Anyway, you gotta stop him. He's going to raise an army of dead and attack the town."

With that, the boy passes out again. You won't be able to fight a necromancer while carrying him, so you leave him here with the intention of coming back to get him later.

In the back of the room, you find another hallway way leading deeper into the compound.  Individual footprints are indistinguishable as the centuries of dust has been trampled down with frequent passage.
You say a silent prayer to whichever god is listening before you get up to go one your way. It is clear that someone left Jimmy in here, and you are going to find out who.

Not far down this passage you find a door on either side. They are identical and both show signs of fairly regular use. You open the door on the left. You find what appears to be some sort of storage room. There are a few shelves with miscellaneous things on them. Vials, scrolls, and some candles in a variety of colors.

He starts chanting to cast something. You try to cast Dispell Magic.

Before you are able to get the Dispell cast, Kevin's hand points at you and he casts Ray of Enfeeblement. A coruscating ray of energy shoots out and hits you.

Roll Constitution to save

You don't quite get the dispell cast in time, Kevin's hand points at you and he casts Ray of Enfeeblement. A coruscating ray of energy shoots out and hits you.

Luckily, your dispell is cast moments after he hits you with the ray and you are able to end it prematurely. The ray made you feel a bit tired is all.
You manage to dispell his spell before he is able to even get it cast. He must not have been in many wizard battle before as he seems a bit dumbstruck. You get +1 Foward to casting a spell.
Now it's your turn to cast something. Since this guy has been sitting in a dark underground lair for possibly quite some time, you decide that hitting him with a sunbeam will be quite effective.
The ray saps your energy, and you fall to the ground. You manage to hit your head on the corder of a table on your way down, and you lose @X hit points.
You feel yourself weaken a bit, but you manage to stay upright. You take -1 forward to your next roll.
The spell has no effect on you.
Kevin goes back to working on his ritual giving you little mind. You manage to climb back to your feet and retaliate.

You try to bring a beam of sunlight into a underground temple that is hundreds of feet below ground. The attempt tears at the fabric of reality. You suddenly get a massive headache and fall to the ground. You lose @X Hit Points.
A pillar of light engulfs Kevin. It seems to hurt him, but he quickly waves his hand and dissipates it.

A pillar of light engulfs Kevin. His fair skin starts to blister and burn. It smells a bit like Bacon.

You have him on the ropes now.

As Kevin sails in the air at you, you step to the side and grab his wrist of the hand holding the dagger. Doing some fancy self defense type moves, you manage to flip him on the ground, take the knife from him, and put it to his neck.

You use the dagger to slit Kevin's throat and put and end to all of this.

The first place you go when you get back to the village is to the Inn to get some rest. In the morning you find the town's guards and tell them the tale of your adventure and the crises that you helped the town avoid. You get a bit of a reward for your trouble.

With the dagger at his throat, Kevin is more inclined to see the error of his ways.

You take him back to the village and you help him find a more productive use for his talents and time.
